Comment: Ah, a kings pawn game.  I think I'll just play it boringly for the first few moves.
Here it starts to get different. Looks like Dad is planning to fianchetto his bishop. I want to try to keep the middle full of pawns to block it in.

I wanted to play Bc5 to get the bishop out and then play d6 to make my centre pawns strong... but I decided on just developing for now.
After castling, his pawn on f2 is pinned.
After castling, his pawn on f2 is pinned.
After castling, his pawn on f2 is pinned.
Opening up my white bishop, and strengthening my e5 pawn.
Offering to sacrifice my bishop. My queen will be following in behind it.

Feels like a gift.  My king and queen are lined up, and Dad has a white bishop handy to skewer them if I capture it with my knight. But, I do so anyway, because if I play my pawn to c6 then that should deal with the bishop.
Things are looking very poorly for white.  As far as I can tell, the only way to prevent Qh2# is to trade out both his white bishop and queen.
